name: Week 5 Pre-Lab Quiz: Transitional Fossils

ratings.long_description:
Question #7
False. Transitional forms are species in their own right. They are called transitional form  because they possess traits, like fins, that are found in earlier fossil  animals, but also possess traits, like limb bones, that are found in later fossil animals

Students  should  explain that from the fossil record, Shubin and his team knew that before 385 mya the fossil record does not contain tetrapods. Around 365 mya the fossil record show the first evidence of organisms with tetrapod limb characteristics, including digits. Shubin and his team hypothesized that the evolution of a functional tetrapod limb was a gradual process, and fossils showing intermediate steps in that process should be located in rocks of ages between 385mya and 365 mya.

description:
Purpose of this Assignment

The purpose of this assignment is to set up GitHub as a basis for the following two assignments.

What to Do

In this assignment you will go through just two steps:

  • Creating a GitHub account, if you don't have one already.
  • Set up GitHub SSH so that there is no need to continuously authenticate yourself over and over again, each time you interact with it from your remote platform.

Step 1: Create GitHub account

Head over to github.com and create a free account, if you don't have one already. Find out yourself how to do that, it's trivial.

Step 2: Set up ssh on GitHub

This step is also trivial, but you need to follow the below instructions diligently. Make sure to replicate all commands exactly as you see them below. If you run into issues, reset everything to the very beginning and start all over.

Go to your ubuntu platform and create an ssh key pair. Go with the defaults, just hit enter for all that comes up. Then cat the public key that was created in the process:

Copy the public key entirely. Be careful with this - you cannot make a mistake, or the following won't work!

Now head over to your GitHub, where you need to be logged into your account. Go to "Settings" and then to "SSH and GPG keys". Click "New SSH key":

Enter your public key in the field provided:

Click "Add SSH key" and you get something like that:

Go back to your Ubuntu platform. In this last step you need to prove to me that you have done the above steps without a hitch. You are asked to ssh into "github.com" as a user "git". Keep in mind that this is only done for the purpose of showing that you have installed your ssh keys correctly, otherwise you would never do this in your day to day operation. Check the output that you receive as a response from GitHub when you try to ssh into it. It will tell you whether you authenticated correctly or not. It HAS TO LOOK LIKE THAT in order to receive any points - specifically the part that says "Hi xxx! You've successfully authenticated, ...":

Mind that you DO NOT log in with your GitHub user name, the user name needs to be just "git"! Take a screenshot of that very last screen, just like what you see above.

What to submit

Submit the above screenshot directly on Canvas.

Grading Guide

This assignment earns 10 points. Your screenshot needs to be 100% correct, or no points are earned at all. You just need to get it right - no discussion.
name: 1. GitHub - Part 1 - Create GitHub Account and Configure SSH

description:
Purpose of this Assignment

The purpose of this assignment is to practice the workflow that allows you to make changes to a code base that is living on GitHub. As you saw from the material that you have watched, this workflow is really a circle with an overlap. If this idea does not ring a bell, you have to (really, really) go back to the video that covered this concept, please click here.

For your reference, here is the schema again that I developed that distills the gist of that workflow:

The (only) focus of this assignment is to familiarize you with the basic GitHub workflow cycle and go through it twice. For clarity, you won't contribute to a repo that you share with others - yet. The latter will be the goal of the last and final assignment that comes next, which will conclude this module overall.

In order to successfully finish this assignment, you need to have done the first assignment "Configure GitHub SSH", which is setting up SSH on GitHub, so that you don't need to keep putting in your credentials when interacting with the GitHub server. If you find yourself being prompted for your credentials when you clone, pull or push, that part went wrong and you will want to revisit that assignment.

Follow Along - Let's get Warmed up!

This first part is intended to warm you up with the workflow, so that you have it done once, before you are on your own. 

Step 1 - Preparation

Let's create a quick repo on GitHub so that we have something to work with. Do the following:

  • Head over to GitHub. Click on your avatar in the upper right corner and then on "Your repositories.
  • Click the green "New" button in the upper right.
  • Name your repo "hello-world" and click on "Create repository".
  • Find the link that says "creating a new file" and click on it.
  • Enter the famous "hello world" program like so:

  • Give that file a name, i.e. helloworld.c. You should see something like that:

  • Click on the green button "Commit changes ...", enter a commit message of your choice or just go with what is offered and click on "Commit changes" - and you are done with this prep.

Step 2 - Cloning the repo and creating your own branch

Log into your Ubuntu platform. If you have not already done so, please install Git - Follow the instructions given in chapter 1.5 - 1.8 of PG, see here.

Clone your repo - see the green step 1 in my schema

Create a folder where your repo is going to live, you will probably name it helloworld. Change into that folder.

Now clone your hello-world repo that you have on GitHub. This is the first step in green that you see on my schema. You will wonder where you will get that link from, that is passed in: git clone <remote>:<user>/<repo>. Well, you don't need to construct that link manually, it's easy to retrieve from the GitHub server. Click on <Code> in the upper left:

 Then click on the green button "Code" and immediately on "SSH" - DON'T click on "HTTPS", make sure to really click on "SSH":

Now copy the link by clicking on that little clipboard symbol to the right of the link, in my case that is git@github.com:dieterotte/hello-world.git

Head over to your Ubuntu platform and issue the git clone command, you should see something like that:

Note that your credentials should not be asked for! Congratulations, you just cloned your first repo!

Create a branch - see the green step 2 in my schema

Not let's prepare for doing some changes to your repo. For that to happen, you will NOT apply your changes to your  main  branch directly. Instead, you will create a branch, in which you will do your changes and then propose those changes to be merged into the  main  branch by way of a "pull request". But first things first, create a branch called helloworld:

This concludes the two (green) steps that are specific to setting up a repo on your remote platform, i.e. your Ubuntu server for the first time.

The following steps you will go over and over again in a normal, "warmed up" phase of your project. These are the steps 1 through 6 that you see in red in my schema above. Let's dive into that ...

Step 3 - Applying changes to your code base

Just for your orientation, have a look at my schema above: you are in the lower right corner. And you are ready to apply changes to your code base, which will involve:

  • Doing a change in the work tree,
  • Staging the change,
  • Committing the change ...
  • and do the whole thing all over again

This is the red step 1 in my schema. In CS205 you have learned how to do all that, so we won't cover it again here. If you are shaky with that, you will want to go back, specifically revisit chapters 2 and 3 of the PG text, see here.

Go ahead and add a comment of your choice to your helloworld.c file, then stage and commit the change. Have a look at the git log and understand why there are two commits:

The next step is to merge your change into the  main  branch on GitHub. This involves two activities:

  • You need to push your change unto the GitHub server. The effect of that is that the change in your branch helloworld on your Ubuntu machine is reflected in your branch helloworld on the GitHub server. This is the red step 2 in my schema:

Go ahed and do this step.

  • ... and you need to create a pull request on the GitHub server. It is called "pull request", because you ask for "pulling" your changes into the  main  branch. The pull request will be evaluated by the repo OWNER - in this case you! Keep that in mind, as it will help you to understand what is going on in the next assignment, when you will be a COLLABORATOR, but not the OWNER ... or the other way around! Once the pull request was okay-ed, your change will be merged into the main branch. Both the pull request and the merge are reflected in the red step 3 in my schema.

Now let's do the pull request first. Go to your GitHub server and click on the green "Compare and pull request":

This step allows you to look at the changes that were applied, before you actually issue the pull request:

Go ahead and click on the green "Create pull request" button, which now allows for discussing the changes. The discussion may trigger more changes that can be added to the pull request - we won't do that here. Finally, the owner may merge the changes into the  main  branch OR close the pull request, which will cancel the whole request. That means that the changes were not accepted. Let's go ahead and merge the changes by clicking on the green "Merge pull request" button:

You need to confirm the merge:

And, voila, finally the merging happened and the pull request will be closed:

Don't delete your branch, however. You will want to keep it for future reference, as encouraged in Henrik's video.

Keeping the branch has a consequence, however, which ultimately dictates what you need to do now, i.e. you need to sync the following branches, in this order:

  • main on your Ubuntu server - this is a git pull,
  • helloworld on your Ubuntu server - this is a git merge and
  • helloworld on your GitHub server - this is a git push.

These are red steps 4, 5 and 6 in the schema - with step 6 being the "overlap" that I mentioned before. All of that is done on your Ubuntu server. Let's go ahead and do steps 4, 5 and 6 in one go and also have a look at the git log from the helloworld branch:

Step 4

Step 5

Step 6

 

And you are done! You successfully finished one complete workflow cycle!

What to Do - Your Turn!

Now let's put your experiences that you made above to work. I want you to go through TWO FULL CYCLES like that:

  • Add a file README.md to your helloworld repo, going through red steps 1 through 6. Remember that you need to do the green steps only in the very beginning and you are past that, so don't bother. To document what you are doing, take one screenshot of each one of the steps - in the very same way as I have done above. There is one exception though: for step 3, i.e. the pull request/merge, only take the screenshot that is showing the end result, which was the last screenshot of the whole series above showing "Pull request successfully merged and closed".
  • Now, do the same all over again (... repetition is the mother of wisdom ...), this time changing the output of the program from "hello world" to "Hello world!". Again, document each one of the steps as you did in the first round. 

What to submit

Convince yourself that you need to have 12 screenshots altogether. Create a word document that has two sections:

  • "Section 1 - Adding README.md"
  • "Section 2 - Changing Output"

Each section has a quick sub header "Step 1", "Step 2" all the way up to "Step 6". Under each of those headers, put the screenshot that pertains to that section/step.

Submit on Canvas.

Grading Guide

This assignment earns 24 points, two points per screenshot. Each screenshot needs to be 100% correct to earn its two points.
name: 1. GitHub - Part 2 - Basic Workflow

description:
Purpose

In the last assignment you have learned about the basic workflow when working with GitHub. Specifically, you have gained an understanding of the interplay between the GitHub server that contains the precious main branch that needs to be accessed and updated carefully in a very controlled way - and the copy of the repo on your remote site, in our case your Ubuntu server.

What we are going to do now is to extend this idea to a team setting. You can imagine that the GitHub server will now become a central HUB ("nomen est omen" - the name gives it away ...) for a whole team, where all of the team members can easily access the (same!) code base on that server. Luckily, and likely to your surprise, that won't change much in the basic workflow. The only thing that needs to be done additionally is to add all team members to the repo as what is called "collaborators", which provides them with clone, pull and push privileges.

Before you do so, however, let me ask you to take a minute and reflect upon what you have done in the previous assignment. Don't skip over it, as understanding what I'm going to tell you will make your life much easier for this assignment. Specifically, focus on the red step 3: remember that you created a pull request, which asked to integrate/merge your changes into the main branch on GitHub. As this is an extremely critical step, your team may want to discuss your changes and provide feedback, before, ultimately, the permission is granted to make the merge happen. But the permission of whom? In the last assignment it was YOU, as you were the owner of the repo and the pull requestor at the same time. In a team setting, those two persons will be different people! And this is already the main difference to a team setting, as easy as that!

For your reference, here is the workflow chart again. I detailed the red step 3 as this has an impact on the separation of roles that we will see in the team setting context:

Preparation

Before we start, you need to do some setting up. Obviously, this is going to be a team project ... we will have a team of two, which is you and you. Yes, you read that right, you will take on two roles: a) the owner of the repository who will discuss and approve of pull requests and doing the merge - and b) the "other you", a plain ol' team member, who is going to do the changes to the code base and asking for those changes to be admitted into main, by way of a pull request.

Step 0 - Get a second account on GitHub

To pull this off, pun intended, you will need to have a second account on GitHub. This second account will take on the role of the "repo owner", while the account that you have been working with will take on the role of one of the "team members". In our case, the only team member. For clarity, throughout the course of this assignment, I will refer to the two different people as OWNER (your new, second account) and MEMBER (the account that you have been working with). Admittedly, that sounds a bit schizophrenic and in a way it is. However, in this arrangement you can make both roles' experiences at the same time, without the need to rely on a peer, which may create some serious headaches of its own. After all, if you don't pull your weight as a MEMBER (again, pun intended, yawn ...), the only other person that you as an OWNER can be mad at is you ...

Now go ahead and create a second free account on GitHub. You will need to have a second email in order to get an account. I'm sure you have an NAU email and another one for your private affairs. I leave it up to you to figure it out.

... okay, are you done? If not, don't even think about going on. Go back and git/get your second account ...

Step 1 - Setting up a Repository on GitHub for Team Work

OWNER, download the nqueens project code from here. Expand the archive on your local machine and open up a Finder (on a Mac) or Explorer (on Win) window such that you see all the files in the nqueens folder.

Log into your new account and create a new repository called nqueens. Now, instead of creating files directly on GitHub like you did before, drag all files in the nqueens folder into your repo, importing all of them at once - watch out for the link "uploading an existing file". Don't, however, drag in the nqueens folder itself, or you will end up with that folder within the repo! Commit the change, with an "Initial Commit" message. Here is what you should be looking at at that point:

Go to your repo's "Settings" and click "Collaborators". Here you will add the one team member that you will have. In GitHub lingo, that is a "Collaborator". And, needless to say, that collaborator is MEMBER. Click on the green "Add people" button and put in MEMBER's GitHub name, which will invite MEMBER into your team. If all went well, you will see that the invite of MEMBER is pending:

Take a screenshot that shows the pending invite part of the screen as I have done above [OWNER 1] 

MEMBER, log into your account on GitHub. Then go to your email and find your invitation:

Click on the "accept or decline" link upon which you get the opportunity to accept the invitation:

 

Here is the thing though: your browser may not like our schizophrenic approach, in which case you will get some strange feedback, e.g. the repo was not found or something else, after you clicked on the "accept or decline" link. If you don't get the green "Accept invitation" button, right-click on the "accept or decline" link, copy the link and go to a totally unrelated browser, e.g. Chrome, if you are in Safari. Paste the link into the location line, hit enter and now you should see the above image that allows you to accept the invitation.  Take a screenshot of that invite offer that looks just like the image above [MEMBER 1]

Now click the green "Accept invitation" button - that will open up the project of OWNER. Here you need to understand that you are NOT looking at a copy of the repo. Rather, you are looking at the real deal, i.e. the repo itself, just like several people reading the same newspaper!

If you heed to log out of GitHub for some reason and get back in again later on, finding the repo is not really straightforward. First you click on your avatar in the upper right, click on "Settings" (... Not on "Your repositories"! You won't find it there as you are not the owner of the repo), then click on "Repositories", where you will see it.

OWNER, go to the page with your collaborators. Reload it, you should now see that your MEMBER has accepted the invitation as there is no mention of "pending" any more. Take a screenshot that shows the MEMBER being a collaborator [OWNER 2] 

 And, OWNER and MEMBER, you guys did it! You successfully set up a repo and can now start working on it together ... with a little bit of creativity, imagine that there are some more team MEMBERs that are all seeing the same repo ...

Now, let's get to work!

Creating Changes and Merging them back into the Code Base

Step 2: Applying some Changes

MEMBER, go to your Ubuntu server and clone the repo nqueens. Remember how to get the link that you need to pass to the git clone call ... that's right, you get it from the repo on GitHub: click "Code", then "SSH" and copy the link! This is green step 1 Take a screenshot of the output of the successful git clone call [MEMBER 2] 

Explore the code that you just cloned. You are encouraged to compile and run it. It doesn't have a Makefile, so you will need to compile it manually like that: 

gcc -o nqueens main.c utils.c solver.c

Now open up the file solver.c in vim and have a look at line #7. Assume that you have the genius epiphany that changing the true in that line to a false will make the program output ALL solutions of the N Queens problem, instead of just the very first one. As you will want to make any changes in a new branch, create a branch playground and switch into it - this is green step 2. Make the change, save, stage and commit it with a commit message "All solutions", this is red step 1.

Step 3: Push and Pull Request

Now remember what comes next ... you will want to have your change (living in your branch  playground ) merged into main on GitHub! So, push your change onto GitHub, red step 2. That will create a copy of your branch playground on GitHub, which is the basis for the next step, your pull request. So get onto GitHub and create a pull request - this is red step 3a. All of that you should be well familiar with! Take a screenshot of the pull request window [MEMBER 3]

Step 4: Review and Merge

OWNER, take a look at the pull request that you will have received at that point. Before you merge, ask a few questions that mimic a review.

MEMBER, go along and answer the OWNER's questions to her/his full satisfaction, after all you don't want to mess with yourself, haha ... Please note that as an outcome of the discussion, you may add to the pull request just by going through red steps 1 and 2 again  ... and again ...!

OWNER, finally merge the proposed change into main - this is red step 3b. Take a screenshot of the successful merge/closed pull request [OWNER 3]

Step 5: Synching back the Merge into the Remote Repository

MEMBER, the rest is easy, you now need to close the workflow cycle by circling back, including the overlap ... that will lead to a perfect and complete sync of ALL FOUR branches - these are red steps 4, 5 and 6. Once you are done with that, call git log from your playground branch. Take a screenshot of that log output [MEMBER 4]

OWNER and MEMBER, congratulations, you are done, this time for good! I hope you guys still like each other ... 

What to submit

Create an MS Word or PDF document. In that document, create two sections, the first section for the OWNER, the second section for the MEMBER. In each of the two sections, put in the screenshots in the order as they appear above. Make sure that all of the OWNER's screenshots go into the OWNER's section, while all of the MEMBER's screenshots go into the MEMBER's section.

FOR EACH SCREENSHOT, you NEED to add a sentence or two that comments on what should be seen on that specific screenshot. Put that comment directly under the screenshot. 

Grading Guide

Each one 100% correct screenshot/comment pairing receives 4 points (or zero if entirely or partially incorrect) for a total of 28 points.
name: 1. GitHub - Part 3 - Contributing to a Code Base

description:
Purpose of this Assignment

The purpose of this assignment is to apply your knowledge that you have gained in the prior watching assignments and create a Makefile that is tailored towards a small software project that implements a simple Web Time Server.

The specifics of the program don't really matter. All you need to know is that the program implements a simple server that returns the local time when hit with a web browser. It is elaborate enough, however, to have some nice dependencies that need to be honored in the Makefile.

Heads-up

Creating Makefiles is a very complex area. You can get totally crazy with it. And perhaps you already have some experience with that ... making Makefiles that is, not becoming crazy ...

In this exercise, however, I ask you to stay strictly within the limitations of what the last three videos about how to create Makefiles demonstrated. I ask you to diligently follow the instructions and create targets, dependencies and rules exactly and directly as given to you. Directly means that you are not allowed to rely on make's smartness so you can rely on rules/dependencies implicitly created for you without spelling them out explicitly. I and my graders will NOT engage in any discussions why your Makefile does work (and it actually may or may not), when you have not honored what I have just said.

In case you wonder why I am insisting on this, here is the simple truth: grading becomes infeasible otherwise, if I don't confine the possible solution space to something manageable. With the number of students that we have, we just cannot afford to get tied up in heated discussions about little details, when you have not followed instructions to begin with. This is based on experiences - thank you for your understanding. 

What to Do

In this assignment you will do the following:

  • Download a small software package that implements a Web Time Server. Copy it over to your platform and unzip it.
  • Write a Makefile that builds the executable from the software package.
  • Verify that the Makefile actually works.
  • Run the Web Time Server on your platform and verify that it works.

 

Part 1: Download the Web Time Server package, copy, unzip

Please click here to download the package. Copy it to your platform and unzip it. Take a screenshot of the directory structure of the unzipped software package using the tree command [1]. If the tree command is not on your system, install it. If you don't know how to do it - well, you are in CR305 ... I expect you to figure it out on your own.

 

Part 2: Write a Makefile

This is the most important part of the assignment, so please implement the below specs carefully, to the letter, see my heads-up above.

The software package consists of a number of files, which have, when it comes to build an executable out of them, certain dependencies. Each one of those dependencies need to have an explicit expression in you Makefile.

Here are the targets that I want you to reflect in your Makefile, along with their dependencies:

  • wts - depending on:
    • webtimeserver.o
    • threadpool.o
    • properties.o
  • webtimeserver.o - depending on:
    • webtimeserver/webtimeserver.c
    • webtimeserver/webtimeserver.h
    • debug/dbg.h
  • threadpool.o - depending on:
    • threadpool/threadpool.c
    • threadpool/threadpool.h
    • debug/dbg.h
  • properties.o - depending on:
    • properties/properties.c
    • properties/properties.h
    • debug/dbg.h
  • clean - the job of this target is to remove all object files, i.e. files with extension .o
  • I also want you to put the program name of the compiler into a variable CC

Furthermore, be aware of the following:

  • webtimeserver.o, threadpool.o and properties.o need to be compiled with the -c option
  • wts is NOT compiled with the -c option, BUT it needs to be compiled with the pthread library. This is done with the -lpthread option, that you will want to put at the end of the compiler call.
  • I want you to honor the directory structure, it is NOT allowed to jumble all files into one folder!

Honoring the above specs, write your Makefile. Take a screenshot of the COLOR-CODED content of your Makefile [2]!

 

Part 3: Verify the proper working of your Makefile

Do the following:

  • Copy your Makefile into the root of the unzipped software package.
  • Make sure that you remove all compilation products by calling make clean.
  • Now call make, and directly after that call ll to show the contents of the directory. Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [3].
  • While you stay in the directory, call touch debug/dbg.h. Run make again. Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [4].
  • Again, while you stay in the directory, call touch properties/properties.h. Run make again. Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [5].

 

Part 4: Run the Web Time Server

Make sure that you have your executable wts ready. Call wts on the command line. Your default.properties file needs to be located in the same directory as wts, if it is not, adjust the path_to accordingly: 

wts [path_to/]default.properties

Open a browser and direct it to:

http://[your ip goes here, without the brackets]:23657

That looks something like that:

 

Once you hit enter, you get something like this:

Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [6].

What to submit

Create an MS Word or PDF document that contains the following:

  • You need to create four headlines, each one corresponding to the first four parts.
  • Under each part's headline, put all the screenshots that you are required to take in that part. Put a sentence or two BEFORE each screenshot, saying what is to be seen in the screenshot.

Submit on Canvas.

Grading Guide

Incomplete submissions don't earn any points. The submitted document's purpose is to convince me that you have:

  • A correct Makefile - 15 pts
  • You can run the Time Server and hit it with a browser request, displaying the correct response - 5 pts

No grey areas are considered, you have to get it right or you loose the points. Make sure to ask the TAs questions before the fact so that you get it right. There is plenty of time and abundance of opportunity.

This assignment earns 20 point.
name: 2. Assignment: Build Tools - Web Time Server

description:
In this assignment I ask you to provide evidence that you did, indeed, followed through with the last set of activities, see here.

What to do

After you went through all activities, you have a working diction installation. Run both of your diction tool, as well as the style tool and apply it to this text. It is worth savoring the substance of that text before you run booth programs on it, as it reflects the profound and deep thoughts of one of the most intelligent people of our time (in the person's own opinion ...) when asked what the future plans are going to be. That the quote finishes unexpectedly does not take away from its beauty.

Take a screenshot of the output of both diction and style.

What to submit

In a word document, create two sections with corresponding headlines.

In the first section, put in all the commands that it took to install diction/style, from the very beginning all the way to the point where you can run the tools.

In the second section, put in the screenshot of a run of diction/style on the text provided, displaying the results.

Grading Guide

This assignment earns 10 points - because it is very trivial, you need to get it right 100%.
name: 2. Assignment: Build Tools - Build & Install Diction

description:
Purpose of this Assignment

The purpose of this assignment is to check out the "magical Makefile" that I gave to you in the last activity, to learn how to use it and to verify that it is working properly.

What to Do

I ask you to do the below. If you have followed along in the last activity, you did already some of the steps. Adjust accordingly, in the end you need to be careful to submit all the screenshots with the correct content. To be 100% sure, you may want to consider starting all over - repetition is the mother of wisdom! 

  • Create a directory magic. Within magic, create a folder src.
  • Copy the Makefile that I gave to you into magic.
  • Copy the complete source tree of the Web Time Server into magic/src. Make sure to copy into magic/src, NOT magic.
  • Make sure there is no build folder. If there is, erase it.
  • Call make. Take a screenshot of the directory tree by calling tree [1]. You will want to compare your screenshot with the image that I provided in the last activity.
  • While you stay in magic, call touch src/debug/dbg.h. Run make again. Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [2].
  • Again, while you stay in magic, call touch src/properties/properties.h. Run make again. Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [3].
  • Finally, without doing anything else, call make again. Take a screenshot of the part of the screen that matters [4].

What to submit

Create an MS Word or PDF document that contains the following:

  • Put in the required screenshots in the order as they appear above.
  • Directly under each one of the screenshots #s 2, 3 and 4, you need to put a short comment that gives a rational why the output produced by make is, what it is. As an example, for one of the screenshots your comment will be something like that: "As the sources have not changed since the last call of make, make finds that nothing needs rebuilding." The other two comments will need to refer to the dependencies between parts of the sources, make sure to revisit Part 2 of the Web Time Server assignment, where these dependencies were spelled out.

Submit on Canvas.

Grading Guide

Your submission has to be complete in order to earn any credit.

The submitted document's purpose is to convince me/TAs that you know how to properly use the provided Makefile and interpret its output.

You earn the following points:

  • Complete and correct set of screenshots, all-or-nothing: 3 points.
  • Correct comments under each one of the screenshots 2/3/4, all-or-nothing: 7 points.

No grey areas are considered, you have to get it right. Ask the TAs questions before the fact so that you can be sure that you got it right. There is plenty of time and abundance of opportunity.

This assignment earns 10 point.
name: 2. Assignment: Build Tools - A magical Makefile

description:
Purpose of this Assignment

The purpose of this assignment is to set up a cloud service, specifically the AWS EC2. You will become familiar with this Service by practically using it in other assignments. If you have, for some reason, already an EC2 instance going, you don't need to do anything. In that case, just skip over to "What to submit".

What to Do

If you haven’t created an AWS account yet, do so first: https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/create-and-activate-aws-account/

Sign in to the AWS console and search for "Launch a virtual machine EC2". Navigate to the EC2 dashboard and click "Launch Instance".

 

Part 1 - Set up EC2 Instance

  1. Name your Instance

Give your instance some name that your are fine with, e.g. cs105, mickeymouse etc.

  1. Choose your AMI (Amazon Machine Image)

In this step you will choose the operating system for your instance. Choose a free-tier eligible Linux option - specifically Ubuntu Server 24.04 LTS.

Make absolutely sure that you do, indeed, choose Ubuntu! I thought I did and ended up with Amazon Linux for some reason that I still don't fully understand. After the dust has settled and you start working with your instance, a tell-tale sign that you ended up with something else but Ubuntu is that apt and apt-get is not available on that system (it certainly is not available on Amazon Linux). In that case I ask you to start over, you have a second chance without needing to pay any money.

  1. Instance type

Under Instance type, choose a free tier type accepting all of the default options, likely t2.micro. Glance at the options to get a sense of the types of things that can be done here.

  1. Key pair (login)

This is an important one! We will get back to that further down. A key pair is needed to securely ssh into your new EC2 instance.

  • Select "Create new key pair"
  • Give the Key Pair a name — e.g. ‘cs305’
  • Click "Create Key Pair", upon which it should download cs305.pem.

Note that what got downloaded is a file that contains only the private RSA key part of the two-part key pair. The public key part is going to be installed for you automatically on your instance. Once you have access to your instance, you can see the public key in  ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.

  1. Network settings

In this step, you will choose the type of traffic your instance will allow from the outside. You need to allow two types of traffic — SSH (so we can log in to the virtual laptop) and HTTP (so we can view our webpage through the browser).

  • Select "Create a new security group". Enter anything you want for the name and description.
  • Keep the SSH rule that is already listed. (Allow SSH traffic from anywhere).
  • Click the checkbox to enable "Allow HTTPS traffic from the Internet" and "Allow HTTP traffic from the Internet."

  1. Configure Storage, Advanced details

You should accept the default options and move to the next step.

  1. Summary

Click "Launch Instance". Then click "View all instances" to see a table of your instances (this is your EC2 dashboard). There should be a row for your newly launched instance. Take a screenshot showing that table, i.e. similar to this:

Note that in the above image I already selected my instance by clicking on the little checkbox. Otherwise, you cannot use any of the menu options in the upper right, that allow you to choose, e.g. "Connect" or to reboot/stop your instance.

Part 2: Configure your Instance

  1. Set up SSH key on your local machine

Navigate to your terminal and do the following:

  • Change the permissions on your private key file. First, save the downloaded private key file .pem to your ~/.ssh directory.
  • Then change the permissions of that file to user read only - this is for security reasons. Without that step, you won't be able to access your system. On Mac and Linux, that is done with the following command (find out yourself how to do that on Windoofs):
    chmod 400 <path_to_key_pair_file>

  1. SSH into your new EC2 instance

For this step you need to know what your instances' IP address is. The thing is that AWS does not give you a "raw" IP address, even if it looks like that. Here you see my instance table, scrolled a bit to the right:

There is a field Public IPv4 address showing 52.15.104.106. But that IP cannot be used directly, unlike is the case with other ISPs, like Hostwinds.com or Linode.com. With AWS you need to go through a hostname that is resolved by DNS into some concrete IP. You find that hostname by clicking "Connect" in the upper right (remember what I said above, you need to check your instance ...) and then "SSH client". You will see something like that:

Pay special attention to the "Example", which has been created already with your specific information in mind. You may want to notice two important things:

  • Your login user name is going to be "ubuntu".
  • Your server name. In the above picture you see my hostname, your's will look the same structurally, but different in the details:
    ec2-52-15-104-106.us-east-2.compute.amazonaws.com

That said, you are ready to ssh into your instance, using the above information. You may not need the -i option along with the path/keyfilename, when you put your private ssh key file into .ssh. But it's good to know that you may put it anywhere, then that option comes in handy:

ssh [-i path/keyfilename] ubuntu@server_name

Type yes to continue. At this point, your terminal is now directly connected with your EC2 instance.

Elevate your privileges: sudo su

  1. Update all of the packages on the instance

sudo apt update

sudo apt upgrade

Take a screenshot showing your terminal window.

What to submit

Only complete submissions earn credit.

Create an MS Word or PDF document that contains the two screenshots that you took above.

Submit on Canvas.

Grading Guide

This assignment earns 10 points if your document shows the correct screenshots, all-or-nothing.
name: 3. Assignment: Setting up an AWS EC2 Instance

description:
Purpose

The purpose of this assignment is to install and run a web server in the cloud.

What to Do

Part 1: Installing and running your web server

SSH into your EC2 instance

Use your credentials to log into your EC2 instance, see the last assignment:

ssh [-i path/private_key_file] ubuntu@server_name

Elevate your privileges

sudo su

Update all of the packages on the instance

apt update

apt upgrade

Install an Apache web server and start it up

apt install apache2

service apache2 start

Configure the web server to restart if it gets stopped

update-rc.d apache2 defaults

Test to see if the apache default page is being served by hitting your server from a browser on your local computer. By default, the Apache web server will display the index.html file found in the /var/www/html directory. Paste the server's address into your browser and hit <enter> - Apache's default webpage should be displayed.

Take a screenshot of your browser screen that shows the apache default webpage. The screenshot needs to contain the location line [1]

Now let's do a few more steps, at the end of which you will have your own website! How cool is that?!!!

Part 2: Installing your own document root on your web server

Configure document root folder access

This step will allow you to use a directory called ~/public_html as document root, where you can put your web content, instead of /var/www/html. You will also want to restart apache to enable the changes:

a2enmod userdir

systemctl restart apache2

Configure your document root folder ~/public_html

First, you need to create a directory ~/public_html, which will be the "document root" of your site, which means that all of your web content will go there. Before you do so, exit out of being root by calling exit, which will change you back into your good old user ubuntu:

exit

Change into your home directory /home/ubuntu and issue:

mkdir public_html

Now, give that directory the correct rights such that you can do everything, the group can read and execute and anyone else can't do anything:

chmod 750 public_html

The problem with this set of rights is, however, that the user that runs the Apache server, i.e. www-data, won't have access to your web content. Let's change that by adding www-data to your group, which happens to have the same name as your user name, i.e. ubuntu:

sudo usermod -a -G ubuntu www-data

Finally, throw in an extra restart of the Apache service, for good measure, as we have applied some changes that Apache will want to know about:

sudo systemctl restart apache2

... and you are done configuring your Apache server. It is now ready to go to serve web content directly from your doc root. In the next step, you will want to check that the outside world does actually have access to your site ...

Part 3: Add content to be served to your document root folder

Prepare Content and install on server

In order to have something to display, whip up a quick web page that you will want to call index.html and put that page into ~/public_html. That will become the default page to be displayed, which the web server will be looking for, if it doesn't know any better. Your simple web page may look something like that, please adapt to whatever you want to have displayed:

Confirm that your server is hosting index.html

Paste your server's address into your browser's location line and add your user name, preceded by a slash and the tilde character /~. See my example above for complete and "proper" input of the URL: 

http://[server_address]/~ubuntu/

Hit enter and, if all went well, you will see the HTML page that you just created!

Take a screenshot of your browser screen that shows that your file is served properly. The screenshot needs to contain the location line [2]

What to submit

Only complete submissions earn credit.

Submit an MS Word file or a pdf file with the two screenshots on Canvas.

Ethan - this is important: for this current submission 10/25/24, please grade according to this

Old Grading Guide

This assignment earns up to 10 points. There are supposed to be two screenshots:

  • The first screen shot shows Apache's default page served from /var/www/html - 5 pts
  • The second shows a modified version of the page with some personalization, also served from the same directory - 5 pts.

-------------

Grading Guide

This assignment earns 10 points if your document shows the two correct screenshots as described above, 5 points for each one.
name: 3. Assignment: Running a Web Server in the Cloud

description:
Purpose

The purpose of this assignment is to install and run the Web Time Server, which you are already familiar with. However, this time you are going to run it in the cloud.

What to Do

Part 1: Build the Web Time Server

Use your credentials to log into your EC2 instance:

ssh [-i path/private_key_file] ubuntu@server_name

Get the Web Time Server from the "Building Software" module. Upload it onto your EC2 instance and build it with the Makefile that allows you to have it build automatically.

Take a screenshot of the output of the tree command, showing the complete tree of directories and files of the built Web Time Server, along with the command prompt that shows that you are on your EC2 instance [1].

Part 2: Configure Security Group

Now you need to make sure that your Web Time Server is accessible from the outside, which means that the port the server is going to run on is open. AWS are very restrictive. While other providers let all ports open, with AWS you have to open each port that you are using individually, for the better or worse. 

What you need to do now is to add a rule that allows the Web Time Server to accept traffic on the port that you see in the default.properties  file, which is part of the Web Time Server package. Go ahead and look up that port number first, then ask "Amazon Q", which is the AWS AI wizard, how to add this "inbound rule". A viable question that I suggest you ask is "how do I add an inbound rule". You can access the wizard by clicking on the wizard symbol on the far right of the screen. Here is what it looks like for me:

Follow the instructions of the wizard to install the rule that opens up the server port. If all goes well, your new set of rules look like that, assuming the port is 23657O

Take a screenshot of your set of inbound rules [2]. 

Part 3: Run the Web Time Server as a Daemon

In this last and final step I ask you to run the Web Time Server as a daemon, which means that it keeps running perpetually, even after you have logged out. Convince yourself that a program that keeps running, while not being attached to a terminal any more, needs to have both stdout and stderr redirected.

One way to run the Web Time Server as a daemon is to use the command nohup, along with the complete command line that calls the Web Time Server. There is a catch, however. While nohup takes care of redirecting stdout for you, you will need to redirect stderr yourself. I ask you to redirect stderr into a file called nohup.err. Also, note that the server needs to be started in the background, otherwise the server will be terminated (even though you started it with nohup) when you log out. At this point you need to draw on your skills that you have acquired in the tools classes up to this point, so I expect that you understand what I just said.

Go ahead and start up the Web Time Server as a daemon. Now watch out for the file that you redirected stderr into, i.e. nohup.err. Take a screenshot of the contents of that file [3]. 

Now log out of your system and hit the server with the browser on your local computer. Remember that the server name is that convoluted name that you find on your EC2 instance. Take a screenshot of the browser's location line and the server's proper response [4]. For me, that looks like this:

 

Finally, I ask you to take a note of the link to your server, which you also need to submit. Make sure that the link works. The TA should be able to click on that link and verify that the server produces the correct result! [5]

What to submit

Only complete submissions earn credit.

Submit an MS Word file or a pdf file containing the four screenshots in the order as they appear above, along with the working link to your time server on Canvas.

Grading Guide

This assignment earns 10 points if your document shows the correct screenshots and the link to the server is working as expected, all-or-nothing.

This is an Assignment. You can tell when you look at it from the Calendar or from the Modules page because it has the Canvas Assignment Icon displayed next to it:  

Assignment Overview

In this module, you learned about Entity-Relationship diagrams as a tool to model the database main concepts from a user specification. In this Assignment, you are asked to apply some of the concepts you learned to identify the components of an ER diagram. You can reference the lessons and required readings if needed.

Goals

Understand client specification and abstract them into data items.

Identify entity types, attributes, and relationship types, as well as the characteristics of these components, such as attribute classification and cardinalities for relationships.

Limited use of generative AI is permitted in specific contexts

This assignment allows for generative AI usage as part of the conceptualization process; for example, an AI would potentially have good ideas about the difference between a weak and a strong entity or about the assumed cardinality of a given relationship. AI can be successfully used in this assignment as a smart teammate who listens to your ideas and gives good advice on how to proceed. The advice can be used as input to the work students do to generate a final assignment.

Students should be aware of the potential limitations of using generative AI for design tasks as their focus is on language mainly, not modeling. Finally, in the context of databases, generative AI will bias the outcome toward relational models, which can result in violations of the ER model constraints. Use it wisely!

Finally, Since generative AI will consider its generic knowledge base to produce its output, its insights can potentially violate the assignment specification. It is your job to critically evaluate the outputs of generative AI systems and make them aligned with the problem specification. ChatGPT (or any other AI tool really!) must be used as a support tool, not as an author of the work!

Any final work submitted by students is expected to be generated by the students themselves, working individually or in groups as directed by class assignment instructions. Submitting final work created by generative AI constitutes an academic integrity violation.

Procedure

Step 1. Make a local copy of the HW1 instructions file.

Step 2. Follow the instructions in the file to fill in the provided tables.

Step 3. Save your file with the solution as HW2_1_<studentID>.pdf where <studentID> is your student ID number (only numbers, without the 'a').

Step 4. Submit the .pdf file as your solution for this assignment.

Notes

  • This is an individual assignment; do not work with others.
  • You may use class materials (including the textbook) for reference.
  • The video below shows an example of how to fill the tables in this assignment.

Need help?

Find assistance during office hours, Live Sessions, or in the Course's official communication tools (Canvas Messages and Canvas Discussions).

Technical Support

Need help using Canvas Assignments? If so, please review the following page: How do I upload a file as an assignment submission?

Only registered, enrolled users can submit assignments.

description:
This is a Homework Assignment. You can tell when you look at it from the Calendar or the Modules page because it has the Canvas Assignment Icon displayed next to it:  

Assignment Overview

In this module, you learned about Entity-Relationship diagrams as a tool to model the database's main concepts from a user specification. In this Assignment, you are asked to apply some of the concepts you learned to draw conceptual models using an ER diagram. You can reference the lessons and required readings if needed.

Goals

Create conceptual models using Entity-Relationship diagrams (Chen’s notation).

Limited use of generative AI is permitted in specific contexts

This assignment allows for the use of generative AI technologies as part of the conceptualization process; for example, an AI would potentially have good ideas about the difference between a weak and a strong entity or about the assumed cardinality of a given relationship. AI can be successfully used in this assignment as a smart teammate who listens to your ideas and gives good advice on how to proceed. This advice can be used as input to the work students do to generate a final assignment.

Students should be aware of the potential limitations of using generative AI for design tasks as their focus is on language mainly, not modeling. Finally, in the context of databases, generative AI will bias the outcome toward relational models, which can result in violations of the ER model constraints. Use it wisely!

Finally, Since generative AI will consider its generic knowledge base to produce its output, its insights can potentially violate the assignment specification. It is your job to critically evaluate the outputs of generative AI systems and make it aligned with the problem specification. ChatGPT (or any other AI tool really!) must be used as a support tool, not as an author of the work!

Any final work submitted by students is expected to be generated by the students themselves, working individually or in groups as directed by class assignment instructions. Submitting final work created by generative AI constitutes an academic integrity violation.

Procedure

Step 1. Read the specification in the HW2 instructions file carefully.

Step 2. Follow the instructions in the file and create an ER diagram for the problem below.

Step 3. Export the ER diagram as a PDF file named as HW2_2_1_<studentID>.pdf where <studentID> is your student ID number (only numbers, without the 'a').

Step 4. Submit the .pdf file as your solution for this assignment.

Notes

  • This is an individual assignment; do not work with others.
  • You may use class materials (including the textbook) for reference.
  • You can draw the diagrams using the tool you are more familiar with, but I recommend Draw.io. For more options, see the Resources section in Module 2: Overview. The video below show examples of how to use Draw.io to draw ER diagrams.

The problem

Mr. Hook has a garage and wishes to control the information about his business. The first goal is to store information about the cars that the clients bring in for fixing. About these cars, he needs to know the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN), the license plate, the make, the model, the color, and the year, so he could easily identify the car.

Mr. Hook also needs to know who the car's owner is, which must be the client in the file. If somebody brings someone else's car for repair, they must have the owners name (first name and last name) and phone number to identify the client properly. Besides the name and phone number, Mr. Hook also needs to know the client's address, which includes the number and street name, apartment/unit number (optional), city, state, and zipcode. The system does not need to be prepared for international addresses (only USA). A client may bring more than one car to the shop. For safety reasons, Mr. Hook wants to store data about one or more authorized contacts, who are authorized to check out the car from the garage, in case the client can't be there. The required information are full name (first and last names) and phone number. In Mr. Hook's business, clients and authorized contacts are identified by a combination of their names and phone number.

Clients can go to the garage shop for shopping car supplies only, in this case they don't have to have a car on the records. About the supplies, Mr. Hook needs to know the supplies unique ID, description, brand, cost price, sale price, and stock quantity for parts and supplies. Besides selling the supplies individually, Mr. Hook may also need to use car parts when repairing the vehicles. In this case, clients have 20% discount over the sale price.

About the repairs, Mr. Hook needs to know the day in which the repair was completed and a description of the detected problem. For each repair, one or more procedures may be performed. About these procedures, Mr. Hook wants to store a procedure code (which Mr. Hook has created to facilitate the procedures' identification), the description of the procedure and the cost. Additionally, when a car's part or supply is used for a procedure during a repair, Mr. Hook wants to know which ones were used. The repair must have a total cost, which is calculated based on the cost of the parts and supplies, plus the price of the procedures.

Your diagram must contain:

Entities, Relationships, attributes, cardinalities, and participation indication.

  • Entities must be represented as Weak Entities if needed.
  • Relationships must be represented as Identifying or ISA if needed.
  • Attributes must be represented as primary key, derived, multi-valued, or composed if needed.
  • Cardinalities must be represented with 1, N, or M only.
  • Participation in relationships must be represented as total (double line) or partial (single line).

Need help?

Find assistance during office hours, Live Sessions, or in the Course's official communication tools (Canvas Messages and Canvas Discussions).

Technical Support

Need help using Canvas Assignments? If so, please review the following page: How do I upload a file as an assignment submission?

Only registered, enrolled users can submit assignments.

Assignment Overview

In this module, you learned about Entity-Relationship diagrams as a tool to model the database's main concepts from a user specification. In this Assignment, you are asked to apply some of the concepts you learned to draw conceptual models using an ER diagram. You can reference the lessons and required readings if needed.

Goals

Create conceptual models using Entity-Relationship diagrams (Chen’s notation).

Limited use of generative AI is permitted in specific contexts

This assignment allows for the use of generative AI technologies as part of the conceptualization process; for example, an AI would potentially have good ideas about the difference between a weak and a strong entity or about the assumed cardinality of a given relationship. AI can be successfully used in this assignment as a smart teammate who listens to your ideas and gives good advice on how to proceed. This advice can be used as input to the work students do to generate a final assignment.

Students should be aware of the potential limitations of using generative AI for design tasks as their focus is on language mainly, not modeling. Finally, in the context of databases, generative AI will bias the outcome toward relational models, which can result in violations of the ER model constraints. Use it wisely!

Finally, Since generative AI will consider its generic knowledge base to produce its output, its insights can potentially violate the assignment specification. It is your job to critically evaluate the outputs of generative AI systems and make them aligned with the problem specification. ChatGPT (or any other AI tool really!) must be used as a support tool, not as an author of the work!

Any final work submitted by students is expected to be generated by the students themselves, working individually or in groups as directed by class assignment instructions. Submitting final work created by generative AI constitutes an academic integrity violation.

Procedure

Step 1. Read the specification in the HW2 instructions file carefully.

Step 2. Follow the instructions in the file and create an ER diagram for the problem below.

Step 3. Export the ER diagram as a PDF file named HW2_2_2<studentID>.pdf where <studentID> is your student ID number (only numbers, without the 'a').

Step 4. Submit the .pdf file as your solution for this assignment.

Notes

  • This is an individual assignment; do not work with others.
  • You may use class materials (including the textbook) for reference.
  • You can draw the diagrams using the tool you are more familiar with, but I recommend Draw.io. For more options, see the Resources section in Module 2: Overview. The videos below show examples of how to use Draw.io to draw ER diagrams.

The problem

Mr. Hook owns a dental clinic that provides several different specialties. A dentist in Mr. Hook's clinic is a person who has license number with the Arizona State Board of Dental Examiners. About dentists, Mr. Hook needs to know, in addition to the license, their name (first and last names), phone number, date of birth, and a list of specialties.

Patients at Mr. Hook's clinic should be able to schedule appointments. An appointment has a date and a time of the day. In addition, it is necessary to know which dentist will see that patient at that time. Different dentists can have appointments at the same date and time, as long as they have different patients.

Patients must be registered at the clinic to be treated. This registration is made on the date of the first appointment and it is available throughout the patient's life at the clinic. Mr. Hook needs to know a patient's full name (first, middle, last names), full address (street, apartment/unit, city, state, zipcode), phone number, date of birth, and gender identification. Patients have a unique patient ID.

As the dentists at Mr. Hook's clinic have different specialties, a patient can schedule appointments with several dentists. For each appointment, in addition to the dentist in charge, it is necessary to know which procedures were performed. A procedure has a registration code, a price (determined by the Arizona State Board of Dental Examiners) and a brief description.

Your diagram must contain:

Entities, Relationships, attributes, cardinalities, and participation indication.

  • Entities must be represented as Weak Entities if needed.
  • Relationships must be represented as Identifying or ISA if needed.
  • Attributes must be represented as primary key, derived, multi-valued, or composed if needed.
  • Cardinalities must be represented with 1, N, or M only.
  • Participation in relationships must be represented as total (double line) or partial (single line).

Need help?

Find assistance during office hours, Live Sessions, or in the Course's official communication tools (Canvas Messages and Canvas Discussions).

Technical Support

Need help using Canvas Assignment? If so, please review the following page: How do I upload a file as an assignment submission?

Only registered, enrolled users can submit assignments.

description:
This is a Homework Assignment. You can tell when you look at it from the Calendar or the Modules page because it has the Canvas Assignment Icon displayed next to it:   . Assignment numbers with the pattern .E at the end indicate that the assignment counts as Extra-Credit.

Assignment Overview

This assignment is optional and the grade will be attributed as extra credit to the Homework grade component.

In this Assignment, you are asked to apply some of the concepts you learned to draw conceptual models using an ER diagram. You can reference the lessons and required readings if needed.

Procedure

Step 1. Read the specification in the HW2 instructions file carefully.

Step 2. Follow the instructions in the file and create an ER diagram for the problem below.

Step 3. Export the ER diagram as a PDF file named HW2_E_<studentID>.pdf where <studentID> is your student ID number (only numbers, without the 'a').

Step 4. Submit the .pdf file as your solution for this assignment.

Notes

  • This is an individual assignment; do not work with others.
  • You may use class materials (including the textbook) for reference.
  • You can draw the diagrams using the tool you are more familiar with, but I recommend Draw.io. For more options, see the Resources section in Module 2: Overview. The videos below show examples of how to use Draw.io to draw ER diagrams.

The problem

Mr. Hook is an academic library manager. He is responsible for purchasing and maintaining books and periodicals, which can be read and/or borrowed by registered users. The library serves 3 types of users: guest users, students, and teacher.

For all the types of users, the library assigns a unique user number. Additionally, Mr. Hook needs to know their name (first and last names), age, and education level. Students must also inform which course they are taking, their student ID number, and the year of entry. Teachers must indicate their departments, a list of courses they teach and their degree. Guest users do not need to provide any additional information.

Books and periodicals are both considered publications. A publication has a unique ISBN, a title, issue number, year, and number of available copies. Periodicals have the name of the organizers, subtitle (which registers the theme of that edition), volume and number. Books has a list of authors, publisher, and city.

All the users can borrow or read books, but only read periodicals. Book loans are different for each type of user:
•    Students: maximum of 4 books, for up to 14 days;
•    Teachers: maximum of 10 books, for up to 180 days;
•    Guests: maximum of up to 4 books for up to 7 days.

When a user borrows a book, the checkout date, expected return date, and actual return date must be recorded. In case of delays to return the book, a fine must be calculated, in the amount of $1.00 per day of delay. Copies must be available for borrowing.

Users can read any available publication. About a reading, Mr. Hook wants to know who is reading the publication, what publication they are reading and the date and time the user checked out and returned the publication to the returning tray.

Teachers can request books for class research, which can no longer be borrowed, but only read at the library. When the teacher requests a book, Mr. Hook wants to know the date when the request was made and the expiration date.

Your diagram must contain:

Entities, Relationships, attributes, cardinalities, and participation indication.

  • Entities must be represented as Weak Entities if needed.
  • Relationships must be represented as Identifying or ISA if needed.
  • Attributes must be represented as primary key, derived, multi-valued, or composed if needed.
  • Cardinalities must be represented with 1, N, or M only.
  • Participation in relationships must be represented as total (double line) or partial (single line).

There may be the chance to earn up to 30 points of extra credit throughout the semester. These assignments will be added as they become available. These are not guaranteed to be offered, do not ask for it. 

Points will be added to final score at the end of the semester.
name: Extra Credit

description:
1. Go to Copilot and give it a creative prompt to write - this could be anything, but I ask that you be creative.

2. Save what it gives you and upload it here.

3. Then go to perchance.org and "humanize" your response - pick a fun one.

4. Save that and post it here as well.

5. Write 100-200 words summarizing something that you learned from this as well as something fun or exciting that happened during the process.
name: Artificial Intelligence

description:
• For this assignment, you will submit a copy of your annotated bibliography and Topical Prospectus for peer review. This must be a completed document containing both aspects. Missing one means you are not eligible for peer review. 
  • You will review two other people’s AB and TP, giving 3-5 comments per page either with constructive criticism or positive feedback. Anything negative will not be counted for points. 
  • You will review two other people’s AB and TP. Only doing 1 without my approval will result in an automatic 50% off as you would have only done half of the assignment. 
  • Make sure your comments are helpful - comments like “it looks good” are not acceptable. You must be more detailed than that, looking for something like, “I really enjoyed your TP! I thought it was so interesting how you decided to focus on true crime due to a personal loss. I’m sorry that it happened, but can’t wait to see what you come up with!” 
  • This rough draft must be submitted into two places: 
    • TP and AB RD
    • TP and AB PR
  • You will download/make a copy of each one you aim to comment on and will do your comments on your copy before uploading/sharing that in the discussion board with the original creator. Just make sure to label whose it is.
name: TP and AB Rough Draft

description:
• For this assignment, you will send me a message in CANVAS following the instructions below. All you have to do is follow them and send me the message to receive the credit. You are to make up your own email/message though - this is an example. Be creative with it! 
  • Topic of Email: Proper Email Formatting 
  • What you need in here: 
    • Give a greeting (good morning Ms. D, good afternoon Ms. Damare, etc) 
    • Acknowledge why you’re reaching out (I apologize for the late email - I was hoping to talk with you about an extension on the paper) 
    • Give me your reasoning (I’ve been feeling sick for the last few days and have been struggling to keep up with my work - causing me to fall a bit behind.) 
    • Tell me the time frame you’re looking for so I can work with you (I was hoping to have until Friday if possible, but any extension would be greatly appreciated). 
    • Give a sign off (Thank you for your time) 
    • Put your name (Mimi Damare)
  • Any messages I get (either through this assignment or just in every day class) that don’t follow this protocol or end with “thank you for understanding” will not be accepted. I will only accept messages through CANVAS and only if they follow protocol.
name: Emails

description:

      • For this assignment, there are two parts. For this first part, you will read through one of the assigned chapters (each group of 6 will be assigned one chapter) and you will take notes on this on your own. Remember to be as detailed as you can in your note taking as these will be shared with the class after the activity is done. You do not need to put your name on the sheet of notes as I will know whose it is when it’s submitted. 
      • This needs to be completed before class in order to participate in the activity. Anyone who comes without their share of notes will not be eligible to participate, thusly losing out on all 30 points. I am looking for 2-4 pages per person. 
      • Make sure you submit your notes with proper MLA format into CANVAS - this will be half of the points. Everyone will submit their own notes. 
      • I will create a google drive folder where I will put all of the notes for anyone in the class to go through as needed. 
  • Part 2 
    • Each group of 6 will be given a giant sticky pad sheet and a sharpie. You will work together to make a bubble map of the important ideas within the chapter. You will then expand into smaller ideas to give examples and explanations. 
    • You are looking for the most important parts of the chapters. Keep some space around the bubbles in case someone comes up with an example or idea that could be useful. 
    • Each group will have 10 minutes to get their bubble maps together and prepare to present. Then they will have 10 minutes to present their chapter, the topics and the overall ideas encased within the text. 
    • When done with presentations, ensure everyone’s name is on the giant sheet. You will fold this up and give it to me at the end of class - points will be put in after class.
name: Reading Notes: Ch. 6, 7 and 21

description:
• This is a one full page, MLA format response to the first module of the semester. With this assignment, you will not only learn other tricks to completing the work, but may also be able to assist someone else if finding a strategy that could help them. 
  • For this assignment, you will reflect on your writing process and strategies for completing this first module. Did you do it at the last minute? Did you start when it was first introduced and slowly go through it? How did you find your sources? Is there anything you did that worked really well for you? Anything that you would personally change? 
  • Part of the score here is completing this assignment and submitting it into CANVAS on time. 
  • The other part is to be in class the next day, with this done, ready to discuss what you’ve written with your group. Each group will be asked to share 1-2 things that they talked about with the rest of the class. 
  • You must complete both parts in order to get full points.
name: Reflection Pt. 1

description: For this assignment, you will write a short 100-300 words on what you aim to do after graduation. What career field do you want to go into? Why do you want to go into it? Why is it important for you? Have you ever considered doing anything else? If yes, then what else was it?
name: My Future
lock_explanation: This assignment was locked Jan 19 at 11:59pm.

description:
• A semester long, journal style assignment - this is almost completely a solo assignment. As the semester progresses, you will locate four big, beneficial things that occur and you will write about them. You will identify what these things (events, personal gains, big life changes, etc.) are and how they have shaped you as a person, student, and human. Always go for more detail over less. 
  • Expand on these with why you think they happened or what it is about them that truly made them stand out for you. You can always start by highlighting where you were in life before this happened, then explaining what happened and ending with where you have currently found yourself. Let this be almost like a journal if you need. 
  • You must be able to show how these have helped you to grow as well as why they are important to you. You must have 4 items in order to achieve full points on this assignment. 
  • Your four “things” you choose do NOT have to be school related, but you must be able to argue this to fit the requirements of the assignment. 
  • Each entry must be 3-5 pages minimum - if your submission is shorter than the 3-5  page minimum then you will be docked. Each submission will be MLA format with headers and page numbers. 
  • This will be one document, holding all 4 items within it. It is a one submission attempt only, so make sure you have hit the requirements before submitting.
  • If nothing of significance happens in time for you to write this, then I will allow you to write about something that you know of or hope to happen in the future - following the same requirements for this.

description:
The top three answers to the following questions will receive these points: 

1st - 5000 pts

2nd - 2500 pts

3rd - 1250 pts

 

This is the question: 

How does the film "Mi Familia" directed by Gregory Nava reflect the concerns raised in the article "The Hispanic Challenge" written by Samuel Huntington regarding the impact of Latino immigration and cultural identity on the traditional American narrative? In what ways do the experiences of the Sanchez family, across three generations, illustrate the tension between assimilation into an Anglo-Protestant society and the preservation of Mexican heritage? How does the film portray the challenges and consequences of this cultural interaction, as outlined in Huntington's thesis?

Guidelines for Success:

  • Focus on exploring ideas, making connections, and showing understanding of both the film and the reading.
  • Avoid simply summarizing the film or the article; instead, analyze and reflect on the relationships between the two.
  • Engage with the materials critically, offering your own perspective or interpretation while staying grounded in the evidence from the film and the reading.

 

Rubric for 500-Word Response on Mi Familia and The Hispanic Challenge 

Engagement with The Hispanic Challenge

  • Demonstrates a clear understanding of Huntington's thesis on cultural identity and Latino immigration.
  • Accurately references specific ideas from The Hispanic Challenge that relate to the themes of the film.

Analysis of Mi Familia

  • Discusses how the film portrays the struggles of the Sanchez family in relation to assimilation and cultural preservation.
  • Connects scenes or character arcs to broader cultural and societal challenges described in Huntington's work.

Connection Between the Film and the Reading

  • Effectively links the film’s narrative with Huntington’s ideas on the tension between Latino heritage and American cultural expectations.
  • Demonstrates how the movie illustrates or challenges the concepts presented in The Hispanic Challenge.

Depth of Insight

  • Goes beyond surface-level observation to explore the complexities of identity, cultural conflict, and resistance.
  • Offers thoughtful insights into how these themes impact the characters and their experiences in the film.

Critical Thinking and Reflection

  • Shows originality in thought and reflection on the implications of the film's narrative.
  • Addresses the significance of these cultural dynamics for both the past and present U.S. context.

Guidelines for Success:

  • Focus on exploring ideas, making connections, and showing understanding of both the film and the reading.
  • Avoid simply summarizing the film or the article; instead, analyze and reflect on the relationships between the two.
  • Engage with the materials critically, offering your own perspective or interpretation while staying grounded in the evidence from the film and the reading.

Questions in this section will cover your academic workload, employment status, and other commitments that may impact your time and energy for this course.
